Abandoned

abandon due to lack of progress/consensus

Unfortunately, the cache is needed so properties changed by users like thresholds are persisted.

I may be missing something, but if you can come up with a method of saving those outside of the JSON then I think we could get rid of the JSON file altogether.

what is the usecase for users changing thresholds via dbus and such?

thresholds are provided in the configuration for PSU, Board, Chassis
there is no need to edit the configuration for thresholds as it is already present.

users can also edit the configuration files in /usr/share/entity-manager/configurations/  and restart the service. the changes will be applied and persisted.

there is no need to have separate mechanism to change the configuration. one mechanism is enough.

the current behavior is confusing and inconsistent. users expect a systemd service to reload all its configuration when it is restarted.

Our systems have never used it so I'm not intimately familiar, but there's just a few writable properties which are specified here: https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/a591d6c0b144ebc81e8175651364b2fa29f05cc8/src/entity_manager.cpp#L64

I don't really know why fan properties need to be persisted, @Zhikui do you know? I think there are probably redfish interfaces for fan tuning.

As for the thresholds I think there are external interfaces to modify them via Redfish and IPMI and they are then saved here.

When EM was first written, or maybe when it was ported over from Intel's world, it didn't even put anything on D-Bus and just saved everything in system.json which is why it even exists in the first place.

I would be all for moving away from it, we just don't want to break the people that need the persistence.

one way to look at it would be that the people using these writeable properties were using EM wrong since the correct values could have been provided by the initial configuration files. which they can update without issue with this new change and their change will actually be applied. 

as changing the properties via dbus is not as flexible and fairly limited, i expect the usage of this feature to also be limited.

There is code to detect fwVersionIsSame() https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/src/utils.hpp#L95. In your use case was the firmware version the same, but json file content is different?

How would a customer/user update threshold, uploading a new json? Through what interface? 

Current implementation, saving the thresholds in system.json is not perfect. For example, FW update may revert that back. An option is to create persistent json files that override the build in config.

customer/user would 
scp myboard.json root@mybmc:/usr/share/entity-manager/configurations/

to upload the new configuration. then restart the service to apply the configuration. with this approach, everything can be adjusted, it is not limited in any way.

I am not sure that is an acceptable method for all users. Scp onto the file system may not be permitted due to security reasons.
We need continue to support ipmi commands to adjust thresholds and the change would persist across power cycle until firmware update or factory reset

Have thought of a new option. 

To provide the expected behavior for people who use file based configuration, we could only write /var/configuration/system.json in cases where there is actually changes being made through dbus properties or other means.

There could be a small print to the journal on each start of entity-manager
indicating that it is using a /var/configuration/system.json,
in the case that someone is actually using that mechanism, or has been using it,
to help users understand where their configuration is coming from.

But that print is optional for me. 

Please let me know if this would be an acceptable solution, to provide the expected behavior for both users
who use file based config and those who want to change stuff via dbus/ipmi.

I have been thinking along the same line, that is whether we can create and save the "patch" config and apply them after entity-manager discovered "base(build in)" config, similar to systemd supports customize service file. 
But, at the same time, I also think maybe we can improve and fwVersionIsSame() https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/src/utils.hpp#L95. work correctly, i.e. detect the configuration/...json files have been updated.

i have rethought the approach to /var/configuration/system.json
it could still be useful to see the entire configuration for debug purposes.

The new patchset prepares a witness file for runtime configuration.
So when runtime config is applied, the witness file should be created,
telling EM to use the system.json file. 

When there is no witness file, everything can be regenerated from scratch, resulting in clean and up to date state according to the configuration files.

Looking forward to your thoughts and review. 

What i am not 100% sure about is the exact call sites of 'writeJsonFiles' which 
are runtime config call sites. However, in my testing, the behavior was as expected.

> What i am not 100% sure about is the exact call sites of 'writeJsonFiles' which
are runtime config call sites. 

That is one of my concerns that we may break some existing use cases. 

> The new patchset prepares a witness file for runtime configuration.
So when runtime config is applied, the witness file should be created,
telling EM to use the system.json file.

Have you thought more about make the fwVersionIsSame detect new config file correctly? From efficiency perspective (in addition to persistent run time changes), re-use system.json when nothing changed has its advantage. If we make the fwVersionIsSame to detect new config files added, it solves your issue. Right?

The new config file cannot be reliably detected based on timestamp, atleast not in my workflow, when working with .ipk files generated by openbmc build system.

New patchset contains an approach which hashes the configuration files used.
To decide if system.json is stale, it just compares the hash.

This approach is really inefficient, as it has to read all the configuration. 

But the  current situation is not good for users of file based configuration.

systemd services should detect changes in their configuration files and apply them.

I am ok with this approach.

> This approach is really inefficient, as it has to read all the configuration.

Did you measure the  timing?

i did not put measurements into the code.

However 'systemctl status' shows 'CPU Time' metric which is about 13s some time after interactive shell is available, on 1st boot.

2nd boot it was 10.6 seconds, 
3rd boot it was 8.8 seconds.

On another boot without this change, it was 12.5 seconds with system.json already in place. 

So the measurement is inaccurate, but it suggest that the  hashing does not consume an excessive amount of cpu time. 


People who care about performance simply remove the configuration files which are not needed.
Make sense to me
Restarting the service wasn't intended to change the state, only on hardware changes was the state supposed to change.
updated the commit message.
Please detect that the detection of new devices works properly.  I suspect that it doesn't anymore, because this mechanism was how it functioned.
detection of new devices still works for me. calling ReScan method on FruDevice and EntityManager results in updated dbus tree when e.g. a PSU is added to the system.
remove this line
whoops. done.

nit: Could you elaborate elaborate on this here in the commit message, that it solves the problem of when copying in new files and restarting the service it doesn't pick up the changes, so it's obvious to everyone why the changes were made.
Adjusted the commit message to clarify new vs old behavior.
Leave it up for couple more days to see if there is addition comments
Isn't this kind of a waste to do at runtime?  Can't we hash at compile time?
To add more, there should be no scenario where we add config templates at runtime, and hashing all the files at startup has the potential to be fairly expensive on the startup times.

I do change config templates at runtime fairly often during development. I can imagine others do so and also regular users who do not want to do an entire firmware upgrade just to add a sensor.

The hashing is expensive but i did go through a few different patch-sets where different options were discussed. I am open to better ideas, provided it has the potential to be merged.

In my opinion it is also a waste how currently all the configuration is put into the image by default. There should only be baseboard + maybe a few chassis and all the PSUs.

Even if we would hash at compile time, it would all have to be hashed again at runtime anyways, to verify that up to date configuration is used.

> I do change config templates at runtime fairly often during development.

Sure, but in development it's trivial to do a reset.

> also regular users who do not want to do an entire firmware upgrade just to add a sensor.

There's no way for a user to adjust these over any public API, so I don't think this is in scope?

> In my opinion it is also a waste how currently all the configuration is put into the image by default.

This is a very intentional design decision, and the "waste" is measured to be relatively small, and could be made even smaller pretty trivially.  Hardware should be supported by default.

> Even if we would hash at compile time, it would all have to be hashed again at runtime anyways, to verify that up to date configuration is used.

I'm not following.  This assumes the configs change at runtime, which there isn't really an API to do, and if you're doing it as part of development, it's pretty trivial to just clear the flags.

i only re-based but seem to have lost the votes :( 
maybe because the commit message was also changed.
Would it be safer to write the file as a hex encoded ascii string?  That might also give us an opportunity for error handling. As written, this doesn't check that we've reached the end of the file.

does the encoding make a difference for the contents? Suppose we do not reach the end of the file and the value that is read is different from the calculated hash.

Maybe due to filesystem errors.
In that case the configuration would have to be regenerated also, since we do not know if it is up to date. Or should there be a different behavior in the error case?

> does the encoding make a difference for the contents?

It allows for handling errors, so yes.  I'm not sure I understand what you're asking.

It also allows for easier inspectability if anything goes wrong.  This isn't a design point I'm going to make a big deal of though.
Please don't write this yourself.  findFiles does this.  As written, you will hash things that shouldn't be hashed.
True. Using the findFiles with json pattern for the next patchset.

This is going to duplicate opening and reading in all the files at startup.  Can this just be added to loadConfigurations() https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/719432e941fd31d0e9bedb91fcfc2034f2fd64a7/src/entity_manager.cpp#L800C6-L800C24

It seems like calling std::hash<nlohmann::json> on the resulting content would be better, as it would avoid minor whitespace changes, and wouldn't require us to load the file twice.

Using loadConfigurations() would be nice but i do not have a good understanding of boost async and its use in entity-manager.

If i would implement it there, would it be called under all circumstances?
And only once and not multiple times?

The decision to delete the system.json is made before loadConfigurations is called.

But you are right, reading everything twice is not good.

> Using loadConfigurations() would be nice but i do not have a good understanding of boost async and its use in entity-manager.

Can you elaborate on what moving the code into the existing function has to do with boost async?  I'm not sure I understand.

> would it be called under all circumstances?

These are best answered by the code, but I think it's called when you'd want to hash.
Nit, please pass by string_view to avoid possible null injection.
Yes, fixing that in next patchset.
